column15: The eCR Use Case currently includes two IGs. An HL7 CDA STU implementation guide (the Electronic Initial Case Report - eICR) for the initial reporting of information relevant for all-jurisdictions and all-conditions to public health from EHRs. An HL7 CDA STU implementation guide (the “Reportability Response”) is in-process for supporting a response following a decision about the reportability of a case report.

column14: ·         Transaction #1 involves the delivery of publicly available, non-sensitive information. Whether it is the download of a trigger code spreadsheet (available on PHIN VADS) or the multi-channel (SMS, email, RESTful download, etc.) trigger / decision rule distribution possibilities of a FHIR value set subscription service, it is desirable to have user’s identity for subscription communication purposes, but extensive security to protect the data themselves is not necessary.
column16:
Need to separate the trigger codes from the rules logic. 

Rule logic is more than a value set.  Why is it specified as a ‘value set subscription service’?  If rules are to be run locally, then there will be a need for a transaction to access rules written in CQL that can then be integrated into an EHR rule engine, or there would need to be a way to get a localized version of centrally-aurthored rules.

the current description does not consider a centralized service, and the transactions required for that. 

Where is the secondary assessment occurring to make sure a case is reportable and to determine where to report it?

I think some level of security is required to ensure the decision support rules related to where to send reports are unchanged during a transaction.  there is a need for provenance of this information even though it is not personal information. Need assurance that the information authored about where eCRs should be routed is secure and not able to be changed by unauthorized parties.

column15:
NOTE: this entry is big so please open the cell to see the full text. 

Current State
To date, eCR has been advanced using a centralized rule-based decision support approach for managing the complex business logic associated with jurisdictional reporting rules. The centralized approach has been used to address the difficulties in distributing and implementing complex business rules in EHRs. The decision support rules are complex for several reasons: 
1. The rules logic for determining reportable conditions usually involves the evaluation of laboratory results and may include complex logic, such as logic dependent on age, multiple clinical findings, immunization history, or other criteria. 
2. The criteria for a given condition may differ by jurisdiction, and may differ over time within a jurisdiction. Each State and Territorial (and many Local) Public Health Agency is governed by different reporting laws, and the sensitivity and specificity of criteria used in the logic may differ depending on the jurisdiction’s laws and goals/priorities for disease monitoring. 
3. The conditions under surveillance differ by jurisdiction. Most jurisdictions require reporting of conditions related to the 74 conditions under national surveillance by the CDC, but most (if not all) PHAs also require other conditions to be reported. Over 200 unique conditions may be required to be reported across all jurisdictions.  

The rule-based approach follows the ‘Event-Condition-Action’ paradigm: when the event has been detected (i.e. using trigger codes), evaluate the condition(s) of the logic (i.e., run the ‘IF…THEN’ rules), and if the condition is satisfied, execute the action (i.e., communicate reportability status to inform reporting actions).  Note that the term ‘condition’ here is referring to conditional rules, not the reportable ‘condition’ itself. 

The first stage of the process requires the identification of events in the patient’s electronic health record (EHR) to trigger decision support. This preliminary identification currently uses “flat” trigger code value sets provisioned in a spreadsheet that EHR vendors / clinical care personnel download and use to match against certain EHR data types: diagnoses, problems, lab test names, lab result values, lab orders, or medications. The current trigger codes focus on diagnoses, problems, condition-specific lab test names, organisms and substances found in condition-specific lab results associated with non-specific test methods (e.g., general culture tests), lab orders for conditions reportable upon suspicion, and a limited set of condition-specific medications.  To simplify EHR tasks, triggering occurs based on a single event. Thus, in the case of laboratory results, triggering occurs based on selected lab test names (LOINC codes); decision support is required to evaluate for ‘positive’ or ‘negative’ results and other requirements for reportability. 

Preliminary identification of an event initiates creation of an eICR, which summarizes the EHR data that will be used as  input for secondary assessment using decision support.   

The secondary assessment stage of the process requires evaluation of the summarized data by a Decision Support engine to:
• Determine the legally responsible PHA(s) based on the patient’s residence and where care was delivered;
• Apply public health agency-specific logic to determine if the data indicates the presence of a condition that is reportable to the legally responsible PHAs; This step involves evaluation of laboratory results and other logic that may be simple or complex. 
• Generate the determination of reportability in an output file;
This second stage is currently oriented to implementation on a common, shared services platform where decision support is required to determine the reportablity of the information included in the summary of EHR data in the eICR. The output of the decision support is required to determine whether to forward the eICR as a ‘case report’ document for public health reporting. In general, PHA’s only want PII data that closely aligns with their reporting laws.

While the event identification function that occurs using trigger codes aligns well with reporting logic that requires only one concept be matched to meet a reporting rule, there are several reasons processing through a decision support engine is required before transmitting PII data to a PHA. First, the trigger code set includes condition-specific codes for all reportable events in the US, and therefore a match may not be against codes that are applicable to  relevant jurisdiction. Second, many conditions include logic that requires two or more concepts to be processed to determine reportablity (particularly, laboratory results where the result value is used in combination with the test name). Third, the specific logic for reporting conditions may vary by PHA and be adjusted during outbreaks to facilitate earlier identification of a case.
column16:
the description of the current state was incomplete and sometimes not correct. I have proposed changes based on the current descriptions used for the digital bridge efforts and current state of RCKMS.  

here are some specific notes of changes I made:

'change 'data type' to 'data element'.  Isn't data type referring to date or string, etc.  

Replace 'Lab results' with 'lab test names, lab result values'.  I recommend this because 'lab results' is a complex clinical model that includes several 'data elements'.  we should be precise about the fields used to match the data. 

replace '-for suspect cases' with 'or lab orders when reporting is required upon suspicion of a reportable condition).'  It is not a 'case' until it has been investigated by the health department.  I am providing more clear language.

the 'trigger codes' are used to identify events, they are NOT on their own to be used to identify reportable events. Trigger codes are NOT equivalent to 'a reasonable suspicion'.  

I have enhanced the text to correct the information that should be shared. 

added: 'and a limited set of condition-specific medications' in order to be complete.  Will be true for TB and a couple of other conditions. 

secondary assessment is needed for decision support

column14:
QUESTION 1. Regarding model a- DS rules distributed to EHR: 

Are there opportunities to incrementally advance some business rules (like only – positive lab results, or location specific reporting) before broad capabilities are available?
column15:
I believe that laboratories should be required to improve the standardization of the results they return to EHRs in order to support decision support and data aggregation and reporting both for clinical care and public health uses.  For example, laboratories could be calculating results relative to normal and critical ranges and standardizing the findings related to organisms.  In parallel, the standards for summarizing lab data need to be enhanced to pull in all the data included in lab reports (e.g., specimen info).  Advances on these fronts are critical for moving forward with simplifying the logic required to process laboratory results. These advances will drive incremental advancement for DS on several fronts. If the EHR systems could easily identify positive results without requireing decision support, then it would simplify some of the logic that is currently required by the secondary assessment currently implemented in RCKMS.   

If identifying 'positive' lab results without DS is feasible, then it may be possible to move forward with simpler rules for diagnoses and lab results that are currently required in RCKMS.  There are many conditions though that have rules that require additional criteria beyond the lab and diagnositic criteria (e.g., age, symptom, immunization history, radiology, etc) or that require combinations of diagnsotic and lab criteria.  These reporting rules require DS logic.  Therefore, there will be an ongoing need for DS.  

While there are opportunities to incrementally advance rules, it will be important to ensure that the conditions selected can be addressed using the functionality available.  It will be a problem if expectations are set that reporting can be automated but the suite of rules required to identify the reportable conditions are not implemented. In this scenario, PHAs won't get all the reports needed and may recieve reports they are not supposed to receive.  We recommend starting with a set of conditions that are reportable across the nation, and that are based on only simple logic including diagnoses and laboratory findings.

column14:
QUESTION 4
The trigger codes in this specification are to be retrieved using a FHIR Bundle resource since they are expected to be updated simultaneously and are versioned as such. The specification also describes how to retrieve them as individual ValueSet resources.

a- Should one or both approaches should be advanced?
b-  How would this be done if the value sets represented a union of different inputs for each one?
column15:
answer to 4a-  The question about using a bundle vs single valuesets is dependent on the EHR systems feedback, as they are the ones that need to implement the codes.  It is likely best for the system to support both formats.  

answer to 4b-  The trigger codes should include version number and the latest version should be used.  The trigger codes should be centrally managed and are dependent on the reporting rules that need to be implemented.  The system that manages the codes should be the resource outputting the files both through the API and some other resource where it can be access manually.  I would like to see a process that avoids manual manipulation, but rather automates the extraction of the valuesets from VSAC and then publishes the files for access through an API or manual download.

column14:
QUESTION 5
EHR vendors have indicated that they would like a common set of trigger codes. 

a- Are there specific needs that State and Local PHAs have for 1) creating additional trigger codes and 2) managing their own reporting rules?

b- How could rules be structured so that there could be reporting to the PHAs of the patient’s residence wherever that may be nationally (vs. the location that care was provided) be enabled?

c- There is currently a single set of Trigger codes that is produced from PHA rules input into the shared public health decision support system (Reportable Condition Knowledge Management System) on the shared services platform. These trigger codes do not necessarily need to be used with RCKMS. Does this approach adequately capture trigger codes needed by public health agencies for reporting?
column15:
answer to 5a- they will only need their own trigger codes if they have rules that are not included in the rules logic implemented. It will be really important that RCKMS is supported to be a usable and sustainable system that allows PHAs to author and manage their rules.  The goal should be to support their needs so the centralized resource can be used to either be available centrally or as the knowledge resource to implement the other strategies (i.e., output CQL or distribute locally). 

answer to 5b. the decision support must include rules for all juriscitions where a patient may reside, not just the rules for the jurisdicaiton where care is provided.  the patient address info can trigger the rules for the appropriate jurisdiction.  this is what is currently occuring for RCKMS on the AIMS platform. 

answer to 5c. the trigger codes are based on the value sets used in the reporting logic defined by the public health agencies. The issue of the adequacy of the codes comes down to whether or not the concepts and thus code sets that are included in the the logic are complete for representing the logic desired by a public health agency. There is a need to get all the logic into RCKMS and a need for PHA's to maintain their logic. There is a 'start up' phase that needs to be acknowledged, and there is a need to support the project.  If the system is not supported centrally, then the EHR systems will need to manage code sets coming from multiple different PHAs.

column14:
Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation Questions:

In non-FHIR EHR implementations and CDA document exchange, the time/date of initiation and the end of clinical encounters have had variable implementation and availability. FHIR has specific data variables for both. 
a- Will these data be more consistently implemented in FHIR for decision support use?

b- How can FHIR be used to initiate an eICR in close proximity to the start of an encounter, while still including a reasonable amount of initial data?

c- Assuming that decision support can be close to immediate and recognizing that charting practices differ in different clinical environments, will it be useful to de-couple the delivery of public health information for a reportable condition from the actual first reporting of that condition (that will have adequate data)?

d- For encounters where a condition has been identified and reported, it make sense to separate next-step reporting for an encounter into reporting on newly identified conditions and reporting on the already identified condition:

e- When a new condition is identified sometime after the start of an encounter, does it make sense to delay reporting on that new condition so as to collect information as above, or because it is later in the encounter should the reporting of a new condition be immediate?

In FHIR, will it be possible to maintain information about conditions that have already been reported for an encounter? If so, in what timeframe should update / replacement eICRs be transmitted?

Should a final eICR be sent at some point after the end of an encounter so as to include all data that were available for that encounter? Is there an approach to setting a transmission for some time or event post-encounter to do so?
column15:
answers: 

answers to b and c- This likely needs real world input such as from the digital bridge pilots, but I would expect that the answer is dependent on the condition.  It is important to note that if the DS logic doing the secondary assessment determines that a reportable condition exists, then that may be enough for a PHA to initiate an investigation for some conditions (eg. measles, pertussis, etc).  They would not want to wait.  for other conditions, it is acceptable to wait.  the 'reporting time frame' for the condition could be used to differentiate those scenerios when immediate reporting should occur and when waiting until later in the encounter would be okay.  I think that is the data field that would be required to drive the decision support.    

answer to e- If it is a new condition, then it should be handled the same way you handle any condition. it should not be dependent of when it was identified relative to the encounter.  The timing of the reporting should be dependent on the urgency with which public health needs the information to drive action.

Questions

3. How would you sequence the different parts of the FHIR electronic Case Reporting standards suite for advancement and why? (e.g. Trigger codes / decision support, the Reportability Response and then the eICR…)
column16:
answer to question 3. 
The RCKMS team believes that the work related to FHIR for the trigger code implementation is a very good place to start. 

Recommend this order: 
1. trigger codes implementation
2. patient data summarization for decision support (which is not described in this IG)
3. eICR generation
4. Reportability response - this is needed, but not if the other pieces are not done.

column16:
Note that as long as PHAs require reporting based on the patients residence, systems must use trigger codes relevant for any jurisdiction that may be relevant for a patients residence and the site of care.  It is not sufficient to only base the trigger codes on the conditions reportable to the PHA responsible for the jurisdiction where care is provided.

Also, trigger code files must be tightly coupled with the associated decision support logic, so  trigger code file management will likely remain a centratlized resource. 

Finally, this transaction description should not reference who will provision the codes, but rather should focus on defining a standardized process for accessing trigger code sets.

column14:
ECR Profile: eICR Composition Profile
Scope and Usage
The Electronic Case Reporting Composition profile establishes the core elements, extensions, vocabularies and value sets for representing an electronic initial case report (eICR). It describes the content requirements for the initial Case Report including:
Patient demographics
Patient pregnancy status
Patient occupation and travel history
Provider and Facility information
Laboratory orders tests and results
Signs and Symptoms and Diangosis
Medication and Immunization History
Flags for the existence of reportable condition trigger codes in diagnoses and ordered/resulted laboratory tests.

column14:
Reportable Condition Trigger Codes (RCTC)

This is the draft trigger codes table. This list of codes is intended use is for filtering encounters in healthcare settings to screen for public health reportable conditions. It is intended to be used in the provider EHR system environment as lookup table to identify cases that should be forwarded to public healthas an intitial case report. The standard codes in this list are directed at diagnosis, laboratory results and laboratory order for reportable conditions. Specifically it consist if ICD-10CM, SNOMED CT and LOINC codes. It may be expanded to include other code systems in future.
column15:
Reportable Condition Trigger Codes (RCTC)

This is the draft trigger codes table. This list of codes is intended to be used to filter encounters in healthcare settings to identify patient records that may include public health reportable conditions. It is intended to be used in the provider EHR system environment as lookup tables to identify records that should undergo secondary assessment to identify reportable condtions. The standard codes in the four valusets (VS) are directed at the following data elements: 
* problems/diagnoses (includes ICD10-CM and SNOMED CT codes) 
* lab test orders (includes LOINC codes) - NOTE:this is a subset of the lab result test name 
* lab result test names (includes LOINC codes) 
* lab result value (includes SNOMED CT codes)
It will be expanded to include other code systems in future (e.g., RxNorm codes).
column16:
The current description makes it sound as though there is just one value set for the RCTC codes and the one value set is applied to all the data elements.  

However, the trigger codes are 4 different valuesets, including value sets of the following code types to be applied to the following data elements: 
* problems/diagnoses (VS includes icd10 and snomed codes) 
* lab test orders (VS include LOINC codes) - NOTE:this is a subset of the lab result test name 
* lab result test names (VS include LOINC codes) 
* lab result value (VS includes snomed codes)
* medications (VS includes Rx Norm codes)  

Again - the codes are NOT to initiate a report.  they are used for preliminary identification of patient records that should undergo decision support for secondary assessment.

column16: This value set is referenced as an 'example value set'. However, every link associated with the Encounter Type value set that you can navigate to, including http://hl7.org/fhir/encounter-type which is where you are instructed to go for the full set, only lists the 4 code defining the example code set. Either a) the Encounter Code System is missing most of its content, b)  its constrained to a list that doesn’t completely describe the types of encounters possible, 3) the link to the full set is not accurate. Either way, the reference should be fixed to either include a link to all the possible encounter type codes, or expand the code system referenced to include more than the 4 codes listed.

column14:
Component Description and Constraints: 

Component Results
column15:
Component Description and Constraints: 

Additional observations related to the pregnancy status of the patient and could include observations like estimated date of delivery.
column16: Effective time of the observation is included, and can be documented as a Date/Time or a Period but only allows for documentation of one or the other. For some reportable events, like Perninatal Hep B, details on expected delivery date or some indication of how far along the woman is in her pregnancy is often asked. The eICR CDA IG, the pregnancy observation includes the estimated date of delivery in the entry relationship. I suspect that the Component Code/value pair is where one could document a similar concept in the FHIR profile using Loinc Code 11778-8. If this is the case, then the description for Component should be more descriptive, at the very least referencing a related observation. If this isn't the case, then the profile should be enhanced to either include another related observation or element for estimated date of delivery, or more clearly indicate where related pregnancy observations should be documented.
column17: Element - No Summary was provided  by the commenter.

column16: The travel History observation valuecodeableConcept is bound to the Jurisdiction Valueset. When you navigate to this value set  by clicking the link in the description (http://hl7.org/fhir/STU3/valueset-jurisdiction.html) the Use Context is listed as "Not Intended for Production Use", and its definition reads "This value set defines a base set of code for country and region, for indicating where a resource is intended to be used". This value sets seems like its more of an administrative value set and the statement " Not intended for production use" is confusing. Is this the right value set? And if so, does it require some maintenance or updating in order to be intended for production usage?
column17: Element - No Summary was provided  by the commenter.

column16: The Travel History observation has an effective time that can either be a single date/time or a period of time. Specifically for travel history, would it make more sense to constrain to Period which would allow for a travel event that took place on only one date within a 24 hour period?

column16: The Composition Author references 3 profiles, the US Core PractitionerRole Profile, the US Core Practitioner Profile, and the eCR Organization Profile. The eCR  organization Profile constrains both telecom and address to must be supported  with a cardinality of 1..*, but is at the organization level. The Practitioner Role Profile lists both telecom and location as required to be supported, but with a cardinality of 0..*. The Practitioner Profile lists telecom and address as neither being required to be supported. The reference to three similar but different profiles with different usage and cardinality for the same concepts is confusing, particularly with no description provided or author in the structure. For clarity, a description and constraints should be provided explaining to the reader the relationship between three referenced profiles so one knows whether or not the address and telecom for the author must be supported and its cardinality.

column16: In generall, all public health reporting value sets are based on concepts valuable to public health, but they fail to address clinical workflow for the provider.  For example, condition reporting may include a set of SNOMED-CT codes, one for each reportable condition.  However, clinicians may use any one of a number of SNOMED-CT codes to represent that condition. Public health reporting , in general, should address the value sets that express the desired concept such that a local implementation can query for any existing condition from the referenced value set and report the specific conditions. And public health entities should be able to determine that the concept provided meets criteria for reporting.  Similarly, lab reporting should address LOINC codes for expected lab tests and their respective results that indicate serologic evidence for reporting. Many current examples require the source to map results (without guidance) to a SNOMED concept of evidence of disease, etc.  The public health community should coordinate with the clinical care community to improve workflow and have better data quality for submission in a more automated fashion.

column15: Transaction #1 leaves an open question, namely a process and an interoperability "standard" (the trigger code spreadsheet) to collect the trigger code data from the public health authorities in each jurisdiction and deliver it to the start pont of the current process, the delivery process.  A nice touch would be an offer to transform the data collected into a form that could be posted on the jurisdiction's web site or other distribution channel.  These data are currently posted on a static web page in many jurisdictions.
column16: Many, if not most, jurisdictions will not be impressed by the additional workload, often at a busy time of the year, to deliver the trigger code data to the deliver it to reporters.  One could even imagine the suggestion that the delivery actor or system get its data from the static web page page prepared by the jurisdicton!  A web application or other process to collect the trrigger ocde data, transformit in to a form useful to the jurisdiction and then convey it to the delivery process.

column16: We think it is important to use FHIR in situations where it fits within the use case. There are use cases within an Electronic Case Reporting workflow where using FHIR is appropriate. However, we should not recreate the wheel in situations where there are existing standards that better fit the use case. For situations like the Initial Case Report, using the existing CCDA format is more appropriate for that workflow and use case and we do not want to create unnecessary burden on implementers to have to support multiple standards just for the sake of FHIR. Instead, we would encourage this project to focus on areas of the workflow where we do think FHIR would help the Public Health and Healthcare Providers complete their workflows. For example, using FHIR to query for additional information after the initial case report would allow an easier workflow for PH and Providers to get all the information they need without having to generate a full CCDA that outlines areas that were missed or next steps for providers.
column17: Index - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: To provide context for an answer to the first question of whether CQL evaluation capabilities will be broadly available for use by public health, there are several open source implementations of CQL evaluation engines, as well as an open source framework for translation of CQL to other languages such as SQL for evaluation. In addition, there is active development of CQL evaluation capability underway in at least one major EHR vendor as well as several CDS content vendors. In addition, there are reference implementations available that support the use of CDS Hooks to evaluate CQL-based knowledge artifacts, and many of the major EHR vendors have stated support for implementing CDS Hooks, so even if an EHR doesn't provide native support for CQL evaluation, a CDS Hooks integration would make the possibility available.
column17: API question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: For the second question of whether an API-based solution would be feasible, it is true that CDS Hooks as it is currently defined is focused on the user interaction, but back-end processes such as eCR are under consideration, and these requirements provide a substantive and important use case for that functionality. However, another option is the use of Subscriptions. EventDefinition resources could be defined for each of the triggering scenarios and then Subscriptions created based on those triggers. That would provide FHIR-capable systems with a directly implementable representation of the Stage 1 triggering.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 1 (general).  A more robust RCTC exchange mechanism has strong value and is much needed; the use of FHIR (e.g., via subscribe/notify capabilities) has strong value.  The distribution of more extensive standardized decision support rules that would include more complex information and especially any processing logic that would need to be integrated into the EHR could be a costly exercise, both in initial development and long term maintenance and support and would be impacted by the differing development/release cycles for each of the EHR's.
column17: triggering question 1 response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 1 - first bullet.  we are generally supportive of the use of CQ and it seems to be a good fit for the needs of a more robust RCTC exchange mechanism.
column17: triggering question 1 response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 1 - third bullet.  The platform we believe to be most heavily referenced for such a nationwide EHR decision support capability is the AIMS platform provide by APHL.  The most recent status we have heard regarding production-ready general availability of the AIMS platform is mid-2018, but schedules should be validated with APHL.
column17: triggering question 1 response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Question 1 - fourth bullet.  The industry has been developing to the initial specifications and agreements which focused on simplified decision & triggering logic within the EHR and thus would not accommodate differentiation on things such as lab result status or location-specific reporting.

column16: While it is useful to specify standards that might be able to enable more specific filtering prior to the initial exchange of potentially reportable information (e.g., via eICR), it is not recommended to delay initial activities to wait for such advancements.  It also should be noted that the business case for such advancements are not yet identified.  As such, the specification of capabilities that may enable more involved up-front filtering has intrinsic value, but should not be viewed as a guarantee of adoption.
column17: triggering question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Question 1 - fifth bullet.  Polling of EHRs for data could have security and performance impacts.  We prefer the subscribe/notify type of capability where updates to the list of trigger codes are published and those entities that have subscribed to updates regarding the list can then manage the retrieval and processing of the list in a manner that is most efficient and effective.
column17: triggering question 1 response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 2 (general).  While this model may have some interesting benefits, if/how this model might improve efficiency and/or effectiveness over the currently implemented centralized decision support model will need to be considered and will undoubtedly be a key factor in any business case for adoption.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 2 - first bullet.  For something like CDS Hooks, the expectation would be that both the exchange functionality and the data that is required to be passed would be specified.

We observe that for model "c", while the potential payload size of each message needed to manage such a centralized decision support entity that is directly called from the EHR might be able to be small, the large volume of such messages that would be required would pose performance issues.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 4.  both approaches should be advanced and maintained for a period, until such time that adoption of FHIR for this use by all EHR's has been completed and one of the methodologies can be sunsetted (if ever).

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - Standards and Technologies Question 5.  We are supportive of the current model whereby public health entities can manage their rules via CSTE's RCKMS and provide a single nationally consistent set of triggerable codes (RCTC) to the EHR and clinical care communities.  We hope that this can continue to be seen as a viable option to contribute and manage rules in this model.
column17: triggering question 5 response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column14: •Public health needs eICRs to be initiated for some conditions when they are suspect, when there is a clinical diagnosis, and eventually when there are combinations of findings
column15: •Public health needs eICRs to be initiated for some conditions when they are suspect and/or when there is a clinical diagnosis.
column16: Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation - requirement 1.  "combinations of findings" is essentially processing based on correlation of multiple data sources.  While within the current eCR workflow, this correlation occurs within the Public Health Agency(s), the management of this type of end-system functionality is outside the scope an interface guide such as what is balloted within HL7.  Inclusion of this as a requirement is not germane to this document, and is speculative regarding business case or market need.
column17: workflow question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation - First question bullet.  Given the wide variation within the industry regarding the definition of an encounter and the difference in such a concept between different modes of care (e.g., ambulatory and acute), it is not clear whether even a well-intentioned attempt to standardize these concepts will be successful in driving useful consistency.
column17: workflow question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation - Fourth question bullet.  The mapping between triggerable codes and reportable conditions is likely a many-to-many mapping, and could vary across various reporting jurisdictions.  As such, it is not clear whether even a well-intentioned attempt to standardize these concepts will be successful in driving useful consistency.  Maintaining activity based on coded values rather than an interpretation of a mapped condition(s) is preferred.
column17: workflow question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation - fourth question bullet. This question presumes correlation within the EHR, some of which may not be the case.  As such, any mechanism regarding "next-step processing", closure of an encounter (e.g., final eICR concept), and/or information regarding conditions previously triggered needs to accommodate correlation within the EHR, correlation within the public health agency, and potentially correlation within a centralized decision support entity (e.g., multiple models of where "state" of the interaction is maintained).
column17: workflow question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: Triggering / Decision Support - EHR Workflow Implementation - second through fourth question bullets. The current implementation for CDA transactions based on requirements from the Digital Bridge collaborative defined the concept of an aggregation interval with configurable timers that could be adjusted to optimize the tradeoff between timeliness and completeness of information contained in the eICR.  This type of mechanism enables clinical users to optimize this tradeoff rather than defining a "hard-coded" universal mechanism within a standard.  The use of FHIR versus existing store/forward or push mechanisms would not seem to have any impact of this timeliness vs. completeness optimization.
column17: workflow question response - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column14: •Consideration should be given to when new standards are ready for implementation and have broad industry availability, but also for a process for sunsetting old standards and what overlap should exist between two approaches.
column16: It is important that any approach to sunsetting old(er) standards ensure there is wide industry consensus on the current or imminent ceasing of use of an existing standard before sunsetting the standard.  Progress cannot be mandated, but rather is best managed by the impact of market forces.
column17: standards transition timing - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column14: •When do you think that C-CDA based standards will no longer be the primary way to share clinical EHR data?
column15: •What might be factors that might drive an evolution from C-CDA based standards as the primary way to share clinical EHR data, and what might be key timing or triggers to such a change?
column16: Fourth bulleted question.  The question, as currently worded, presumes there will be a point in time where C-CDA-based IGs for eICR and RR should not be the primary  way to share clinical EHR data.  The exchange of the triggered information lends itself quite well to a more asynchronous exchange methodology.  Thus, the C-CDA-based standards may be the optimal exchange methodology for the initial exchange, while FHIR-based methodologies would be optimized for more transactional dialogue between clinical care and public health after the initial exchange.
column17: standards transition timing - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column16: First bulleted questions.  FHIR is currently sufficiently adopted to warrant the proactive specifications proposed within this ballot.  Market forces will ultimately define if/when evolutions to a FHIR-based methodology might replace other existing methodologies, but for many of the new transactional interactions identified in this ballot, existing FHIR measures augmented with items as noted within the ballot should be able to support the noted technical and market interactions.
column17: standards transition timing - No summary was provided by the commenter.

column14: There is currently a single set of Trigger codes that is produced from PHA rules input into the shared public health decision support system (Reportable Condition Knowledge Management System) on the shared services platform. These trigger codes do not necessarily need to be used with RCKMS. Does this approach adequately capture trigger codes needed by public health agencies for reporting?
column16: More familiarity with the RCKMS is necessary, including how RCKMS is scalable.
